prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(1-0) in a group of isolated galaxies

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to have at least a peak intensity of ~ 50 mJy/beam for the CO(1-0) in the targets according to our IRAM-30m detections. We note that our rms is about 15 times better than our IRAM-30m observations to detect the weak emission and the previously non-detected galaxies (10 galaxies). To have a SNR>3 in the outer part of the galaxies, we request a rms of 2 mJy for the mapping of these galaxies. We have gathered the maximum of targets within 10 degrees to minimize the calibration times.

We want to cover the CO(1-0) in the galaxy sample with at spectral window of 5000 km/s (about 10 times the typical width of a CO(1-0) line) and a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. That spectral resolution is sufficient to have at least 5 contiguous channels (~ 100 km/s) in the bulge region.
We want to be able to detect the fines kinematic structures in the bulge to better constrain the dynamics. That the main reason why we do not request a spectral averaging.

At the typical distance of the galaxies in the sample 0.5" for the spatial resolution is about 10 times finer than the smaller pseudobulge we want to map in CO(1-0). This will allow us to resolve and map the distribution and dynamics of the CO(1-0) emission. Grouping os sources by RA has been prioritized vs. reducing angular resolution for the larger pseudobulges, since this way the total time has been highly optimized (6.3h in total) while the snr allows mapping till R25.
The LAS is at least about the pseudobulge size we want to map. For the sources with larger bulges (see Table 1) we do not expect molecular structures larger than 7" (2 kpc at the mean distance of our sample).
We checked with CASA simulations that observations for the sources with declination larger than 30 degrees are sufficient to provide a good imaging. The beam is not more elongated than a factor 1.5

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Despite the widespread idea that pseudobulges grow continuously via star formation, AMIGA sample of highly isolated galaxies is dominated by discs hosting red pseudobulges, consistent with an early formation epoch and scant subsequent growth. Only single dish studies of the molecular gas in isolated galaxies have been feasible so far, and those suggest it to be more extended than in denser environments, where gravitational torques/accretion from companions might play a dominant role in increasing SFE when compared to bars or gas accretion from the cosmic web.
Although segregating the full range of environmental effects is crucial, most current studies mix galaxies residing in very different environments, and a reference sample where environmental effects are minimized is missing.
We propose to map a sample of 18 very isolated galaxies in the CO(1-0) line with ALMA at 0.5" resolution in order to investigate differences in molecular gas distribution/kinematics between: disc/pseudobulges, barred/non barred, and compare with samples in denser environments.
Solely ALMA can both map the disc of a significant sample of isolated galaxies and resolve their small pseudobulges in ~ 6h.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Facultad de Ciencias Fisicas, Universidad Complutense de Madrid

School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of
